name: cis-1,4-dimethylcyclohexane
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.

name: cis-1,4-dimethylcyclohexane
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: The basic unit, cyclohexane, has a melting point of 6.5°C. Each methyl group on cyclohexane can have two potential effects: 1) it can increase the melting point due to the addition of molecular weight and steric hindrance, but 2) it can also decrease the melting point if the addition disrupts the crystal packing efficiency. In this case, cis-1,4-dimethylcyclohexane has two methyl groups in a cis configuration, which can disrupt the crystalline structure due to steric hindrance more than trans isomers, resulting in a more significant decrease in melting point. If each methyl group contributes approximately +5°C for increased molecular weight and steric hindrance, but the cis configuration results in a -50°C decrease due to substantial packing disruption, the combined effect results in a decrease of approximately -40°C from the base value.

name: cis-1,4-dimethylcyclohexane
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: The basic unit, cyclohexane, has a melting point of 6.5°C. Each methyl group on cyclohexane can have two potential effects: 1) it could increase the melting point due to the addition of molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, but 2) it may also decrease the melting point if the addition disrupts crystal packing efficiency. In cis-1,4-dimethylcyclohexane, the two methyl groups are on the same side of the cyclohexane ring, which tends to increase steric hindrance and therefore could disrupt the packing more compared to a trans configuration. Predicting the exact effect quantitatively is complex, but we can estimate the effects based on general trends. If each methyl group increases the melting point by about +5°C due to increased molecular weight but the cis arrangement results in a -50°C decrease from the base value of cyclohexane because of a greater disruption in crystal packing, the net effect would be a -40°C decrease per methyl group. However, since the actual value shows that the melting point is significantly lower than the base melting point of cyclohexane, the disruption must be larger than the estimated -40°C per methyl group. Hence, the decrease due to packing disruption is likely more significant.
